original_thought_pattern: I'm consumed by the fact that nothing matters, not even my own existence. Every decision, every achievement, is just a fleeting moment of insignificance in an endless void. Why bother trying to find meaning when it's all just going to end anyway?
transformed_thought_pattern: I'm surprised by how my mood shifts based on my daily activities. At 10am, I was anxious about not making progress on a project, but after taking a short walk outside and doing some stretching exercises (Avoided), my mood went from a 4 to a 6. Later at 2pm, I forced myself to engage with a creative task and my mood actually jumped to an 8! I'm starting to see that the things I do have more of an impact on my emotions than I initially thought.

- Track patterns over 1 week

original_thought_pattern: I'm just so tired of feeling trapped in this miserable existence. Death feels like the only way to escape the constant anxiety and hopelessness that's suffocating me – it's like, what's the point of continuing when everything is just a never-ending struggle? Maybe ending it all will finally bring some peace.
transformed_thought_pattern: I'm remembering the series of events that led me to feel trapped – the beginning was when I lost my job, then came the struggles with finding a new one, middle was when I felt like I couldn't connect with anyone, and end was when I realized I had no savings left. Emotions during this time were frustration, despair, and fear. I'm seeing patterns of self-doubt and hopelessness emerge. These feelings aren't suffocating me; they're just a part of the experience.

exercise_content:
**For overwhelming experiences:**

- Draw a line across a paper
- Mark "Beginning," "Middle," "End"
- Fill in only facts first (what actually happened)
- Add emotions in a different color
- Add meanings/interpretations in a third color
- Notice which parts feel most confusing or fragmented

"My stupid mistakes, they're all I can think about. Why did I have to mess up again? If only I hadn't said/done that one thing... now it's ruined."

I was worried about making a good impression and didn't think before speaking. During that moment, I felt anxious and embarrassed. Later on, when I replayed it in my head, I added shame and self-doubt. Looking back, I can see that there were multiple factors at play.

The photo of that sunny day with friends makes me realize there are moments when life feels genuinely worth living. And that letter from my loved one... it's a harsh reminder of the impact my absence would have. Maybe it's time to re-record that voice memo, focusing on something I'd actually like to see happen in the world instead of just drifting through existence.

The part of me that wants to live is still here, even if it's quiet." Open your Hope Kit. Read one card. The suicidal part of your brain is not the part making decisions right now. The part reading these words is.*

**RIGHT NOW - Executive Function Reset:***Your brain feels scattered, like trying to hold water in your hands. Everything feels urgent and impossible at the same time. You can't focus, can't prioritize, can't even figure out where to start. Time for a cognitive reboot:*

*Write down every task swirling in your head - don't organize, just dump them on paper. Now circle ONE that takes less than 10 minutes. Do only that one thing. When it's done, your executive function will have one success to build on. That's how you restart an overwhelmed cognitive system - one concrete completion at a time.*

exercise_content:
**When you catch yourself ruminating:**

- STOP and ask: "Am I trying to solve something or just spinning?"
- Write down the "Why" question you're asking yourself
- Rewrite it as a "How" or "What" question
- Example: "Why did this happen to me?" → "What specific step can I take today?"

original_thought_pattern: I've been replaying scenarios in my head, thinking about how to do it without leaving a mess for anyone else. Maybe if I time it right, no one will even notice until the police find me, and that way everyone can move on from this pain. My brain keeps spinning through all the details, trying to make sure nothing goes wrong.
transformed_thought_pattern: I've been replaying scenarios in my head, thinking about how to take a short walk without worrying about others noticing. Maybe if I pace myself, I can focus on the sensation of my feet touching the ground and the fresh air without getting caught up in worst-case scenarios. My brain is still spinning through details, but now it's imagining the possibility of feeling a slight boost afterwards.

exercise_content:
**This Week:** Pick one avoided activity, make specific predictions

- "If I go for a 10-minute walk, I predict I will feel ___"
- "I expect my energy level will be ___ afterward"
- "I think it will take ___ effort to complete"
Do the activity, then record actual results. Compare.

**RIGHT NOW - Activation Rescue:***You're sinking into that familiar quicksand of "nothing matters" and "I can't do anything." Your brain is telling you to stay in bed, scroll your phone, avoid everything. Here's what you're going to do in the next 5 minutes:*

*Stand up. Don't think about it, just do it. Walk to your kitchen. Get a glass of water and drink the whole thing. Now do ONE thing - wash one dish, make your bed, or step outside for 30 seconds. Notice: did your mood shift even 5%? Your brain just proved it can change its own chemistry through behavior. That's the evidence you needed.*
